title-group.article-title: Ownership and Production Costs: Choosing between Public Production and Contracting-Out in the Case of Swedish Refuse Collection

abstract.p: Many comparisons of public and private firms use a public/private ownership dummy variable to capture cost differences. If, however, public and private firms use different production technologies, the dummy-variable approach is misspecified. Data from public and private firms should not be pooled. Secondly, selectivity bias may arise, making it more difficult to identify cost differentials that actually exist. Thirdly, if data should be pooled, the resulting empirical model may be logically inconsistent. This paper compares public and private firms using the refuse collection costs of 170 firms in 115 Swedish municipalities. First, public production costs were 6 per cent lower than private production costs. Secondly, cost differences did not affect producer choice. It is crucial to adjust for selectivity. Data for private and public firms should not be pooled. The dummy-variable model is misspecified.

p.mixed-citation: The literature on privatisation is extensive; Vickers and Yarrow (1988) and Bös (1991) are two early contributions.
More specifically, they argue for using a frontier approach — for example, data envelopment analysis (DEA) — for measuring productive efficiency.
Other surveys are Bennett and Johnson (1980), Pestieau and Tulkens (1993) and Tang (1997).
Szymanski and Wilkins (1993) and Szymanski (1996) are exceptions. These studies use panel data.
Marcinèin and van Wijnbergen (1997) show that it is crucial to take selection into account also when studying the effects of privatisation.
The terminology is from Maddala (1983). Heckman (1978) and Maddala and Lee (1976) also discuss this.
Dubin and Navarro (1988, p. 219) ask; 'if private monopoly is the efficient, cost-minimizing alternative, why do over half of the local communities choose other forms of market organization?'.

Why should refuse collection be compulsory and publicly provided? What is the market failure? Consumption of collection services is rival and exclusion is possible. The reasons are general health and sanitation. Externalities exist because individuals are jointly damaged by deteriorations in the environment when some individuals choose low (or no) levels of collection services. The deteriorations are characterised by indivisibilities and exclusion is difficult or impossible.
Currently, public procurement must be done in accordance with the 1992 public procurement law that came into effect in 1994. This law is much stricter than the previous guidelines.
In most estimations of cost functions, I can only use 47 public firms and 75 private firms. As far as I can test, however, this subsample is representative of the full sample.

There are many papers studying ownership effects on refuse collection costs using the dummy-variable approach. Among them are Hirsch (1965), Kemper and Quigley (1976), Kitchen (1976), Collins and Downes (1977), Pommerehne and Frey (1977), Stevens (1978), McDavid (1985), Dornberger, Meadowcroft and Thompson (1986), Tickner and McDavid (1986), Dubin and Navarro (1988), Szymanski and Wilkins (1993), Szymanski (1996), Gradus and Dijkgraaf (1997) and Reeves and Barrow (2000). Edwards and Stevens (1978) use the dummy-variable method to study refuse collection prices. There are also other studies of refuse collection. Cubbin, Dornberger and Meadowcroft (1987) and Bosch, Pedraja and Suàrez-Pandiello (2000) use DEA approaches to study productive efficiency. Some studies simply compare refuse collection costs or prices without controlling for other variables. Savas (1977a, 1977b and 1981) and Bennett and Johnson (1979) are among these.
I have used the LIMDEP version 7.0 software package — see Greene (1995) — and the Stata release 7.0 software package — see StataCorp (2001 ).
Most of the previous studies using the dummy-variable method also find that private production is cheaper Collins and Downes (1977), however, report the opposite result.
Not all explanatory variables may have an influence in both equations. For some elements of X, the ßpr and ßpu coefficients in the cost functions may be zero.
The observed variable Pr = 1 if Pr* > 0 and Pr = 0 if Pr* < 0.
Heckman (1978, p. 936) also provides a proof of this proposition.
The results are available from the author on request.
The determinants of producer choice are also discussed in Sonenblum, Kirlin and Ries (1977), Dubin and Navarro (1988), Szymanski (1996) and Dijkgraaf, Gradus and Melenberg (2003).

Bivand and Szymanski (2000) and Gômez-Lobo and Szymanski (2001), on the other hand, find political effects on costs using UK data. Local governments led by the Conservatives have lower costs than those led by Labour.

I have tried several other variables capturing different aspects of the finances of the municipality without getting any significant result. Among the variables tried without success are expenditure per capita, revenue per capita, central government grants per capita, tax base per capita, tax rate, tax revenue per capita, net worth per capita and the share of the population reporting income.
Dubin and Navarro (1988) also test for selectivity, but this is rejected in their case.

I have tried the dummy variables for sealed-bids competitive tendering and cost analysis in the cost functions. The estimated coefficients were not significant. I have also tried the number of bids in the cost function for private firms. The estimated coefficient was not significant. The estimation results are available from the author on request.
